awd_titl_txt: Formation and Elimination of Segmetation and Transform Faults on the Reykjanes Ridge
awd_abstract_narration:
Seafloor spreading centers?the volcanic ridges where Earth?s tectonic plates separate and form oceanic crust?are subdivided into ?segments? that represent basic units of volcanic crustal formation. Segments are typically tens to hundreds of kilometers long and form crust along their length but with decreased thickness toward the segment ends. Often the segments are offset from each other along shear zones called transform faults. The scars produced by transform faults, referred to as fracture zones, trace out the motion of the plates and are among the longest and most prominent features of ocean basins. The segmented nature of volcanic crustal production on seafloor spreading centers creates the large-scale structure of the seafloor and controls the way in which material from the shallow mantle flows, melts and is emplaced to form the layered oceanic crust that forms two-thirds of the surface of the Earth. Yet segmentation is a dynamic aspect of seafloor spreading and can evolve abruptly or progressively. Segments can form, grow, shorten or be eliminated by merging together with other segments. What controls this evolution has long been a subject of debate and controversy. Some models propose that large-scale variations in flow and temperature of the underlying mantle are important. Other models propose a predominant control by the motion of the tectonic plates themselves. This project will conduct a marine geophysical survey to examine what controls the formation, evolution and elimination of segmentation on the Reykjanes Ridge, a 1000-km-long seafloor spreading center in the North Atlantic Ocean south of Iceland. In order to study what may be controlling this evolution this project will map how the segments first formed following the abrupt change in plate motion and how they progressively re-merged to eliminate segmentation along the gradient in mantle melting away from Iceland. The project will support the training and education of a graduate student in the research and bring undergraduates and interns out on the research vessel for at sea experience and training. A movie will be made of the ridge segmentation evolution to help explain the processes involved in plate tectonics.

The Reykjanes Ridge is probably the best example of the systematic formation and elimination of segmentation and transform faults on Earth today. The project will survey two conjugate flank areas of the Reykjanes Ridge where segmentation and transform faults formed and were subsequently eliminated.  The survey will span the area from near the Iceland shelf in the north to the Bight Fracture Zone in the south, encompassing the prominent gradient in mantle melting away from Iceland.  The survey will use multibeam swaths and sub-bottom sonar profiles to map the tectonic and volcanic structure of the seafloor, towed magnetometer measurements to accurately map the magnetic lineations that date the crustal formation process, and ship gravimeter measurements to estimate crustal thickness changes. These data will be used to examine how variations in mantle melting and plate motion changes affect the formation, evolution and elimination of segmentation on mid-ocean ridges that frame the large-scale tectonic and crustal structure of entire ocean basins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The theory of plate tectonics well-describes the large-scale motion over millions of years of the mosaic of lithospheric plates that form Earth's outer solid surface. However, the evolution of the plate boundaries themselves is not addressed by this theory and remains poorly understood. Our project "Formation and Elimination of Segmentation and Transform Faults on the Reykjanes Ridge" was planned to determine how seafloor spreading centers and their bounding transform faults evolve in time in order to better understand the controlling mechanisms. We selected the Reykjanes Ridge because this plate boundary has evolved in a highly organized manner. It also overlies the Iceland "hotspot", an anomalous region where mantle melting, a strong control on ridge properties, steadily increases toward Iceland.

The Reykjanes Ridge originated as a linear axis without transform faults. Following an abrupt change in plate opening direction, its southern two-thirds broke up into new segments bounded by transform faults oriented in the new opening direction but its northern third remained linear and in its original configuration. Over the next 37 million years, the offset southern segments systematically reassembled the original linear configuration of the ridge from north to south, eliminating the bounding transform faults. The Reykjanes Ridge today has re-established its original configuration as a nearly 1000-km-long linear spreading center without transform faults.

To document this evolution, we conducted a marine geophysical survey using multibeam sonar and acquiring magnetic and gravity measurements spanning the ridge flanks. As the crust volcanically forms at the ridge axis, iron bearing minerals record the Earth's magnetic field polarity at the time the crust solidifies. The ship magnetometer can detect these polarity reversals and thus map out their distinctive patterns, which are associated with known ages called isochrons. We then assembled the available magnetic data from previous cruises, using our new data to correct each cruise to a common level, to make a new magnetic map and determine the regional pattern of magnetic polarity reversals and thus the age isochrons. Each isochron maps the position of the corresponding ridge segment at polarity reversal times and thus their ensemble maps out the spatial evolution of all of the ridge segments over the history of seafloor spreading of the Reykjanes Ridge.

Using this isochron mapping we were able to determine that each ridge segment systematically migrated back to its original location by asymmetric spreading, but they did this progressively from north to south. However, even as the ridge segments realigned, the bounding transform faults were not automatically eliminated.  This occurred when buoyant mantle upwelling instabilities propagated from north to south across the discontinuities, erasing the crustal deficit of the transform discontinuity. Such buoyant instabilities have been proposed to generally characterize ridge segmentation at slow-spreading ridges, but on the Reykjanes Ridge, they rapidly propagate along the linear axis, likely driven by the regional hotspot gradient in mantle melting.  

On the Reykjanes Ridge, we further propose that the deep part of the mantle melting zone beneath the ridge remained linear even after the change in opening direction occurred.  This is based on modeling of the plate-driven pattern of mantle upwelling produced by the segmented and linear plate boundary geometries. With depth, the upwelling patterns approach the same linear geometry for both cases. At the Reykjanes Ridge, the propagating buoyant upwelling instabilities help maintain the linearity of the deep melting zone, which appears to have induced the offset segments to migrate back to their original configuration. Outside of this hotspot influence, normal mantle has small but irregularly distributed chemical variations that affect mantle melting.  Thus, at normal slow spreading systems ridge segmentation evolves in irregular ways. The strong regional hotspot melting gradient along the Reykjanes Ridge overwhelms such small irregular variations and produces a systematic southward migration of the melting centers.

Our analysis of the gravity data shows different patterns between the linear Reykjanes Ridge today and segments of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge to the south. Gravity variations reflect the pattern of mantle melting and indicate that on the Reykjanes Ridge melting is largely two-dimensional whereas on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge to the south it is three-dimensional, forming focused centers beneath each segment. Mantle melting produces not only the crust, but also changes the composition of the underlying residual mantle from which the melt is extracted. In particular, melting extracts water from the mantle which greatly affects its strength. The different gravity patterns imply a uniformly strong residual mantle beneath the linear Reykjanes Ridge, accounting for its lack of transform faults, but a segmented weak-and-strong pattern beneath the Mid-Atlantic Ridge segments, facilitating the formation of transform faults there.

Broader impacts of our project included significant international collaborations on the cruise and subsequent study. It also provided internship experience for three undergraduates seeking training in STEM fields, and academic and research experience for our graduate research assistant.
